alternatives.transcript: USA the one and only Channel 9 Welcome To Face the Nation I'm Lesley Stahl fried chicken steak barbecue ice cream and Cherry Pie the recipe for a fabulous Fourth of July picnic but for a nation that is dangerously overweight it's also a recipe filled with fat cholesterol and salt which equals heart disease because Americans are eating smart exercising more and giving up smoking the battle against heart disease

just slowly being one death rates are down okay was involved in the death of Len Bias this is a drug that can have a very prominent effects on the heart and on blood pressure but as we declare Victory a new worry an alarming increase in heart problems among those who use cocaine Americans are exercising their hearts out and hopes of reducing blood pressure keeping weight off living longer or

spending Millions on weight loss clinics and fad diets that promise to slim you down and take a load off your heart within two to three weeks you'll feel an energy charge like you've never had before in your life isn't that worth four hundred ninety five dollars but doctors are issuing new warnings about overdoing it some fad diets they say are nutritionally unsafe and as for exercise there are warnings about increased bone injuries and fertility problems among women but others point to the risks of

exercising the risks are of course obesity and and heart disease and for women osteoporosis who is at greatest risk for heart disease will ask the Surgeon General dr. C Everett Koop does cocaine cause heart failure will ask dr. David Smith of the Haight-Ashbury clinic and we'll have a debate whether exercise and dieting are harmful to your health heart disease the new risks and issue

I'm facing the nation from CBS News Washington Face the Nation with White House correspondent Lesley Stahl with us to talk about the effects of cocaine on the heart is dr. David Smith founder and medical director of the Haight-Ashbury Clinic in San Francisco dr. Smith you see a lot of cocaine addicts from your own observation how pervasive is this

of cocaine-induced heart failure it's a major problem we've seen in the San Francisco Bay Area since 1978 over a 500% increase in cocaine overdose deaths and the major mechanism of death is a cocaine-induced seizure and ventricular fibrillation cocaine elevates the blood pressure elevates the heart rate you also see cocaine producing a release in brain chemical

manners primarily norepinephrine with the heart being sensitized as a result of the alteration and electrical rhythm of both the brain and the heart so when you see this rapid increase in norepinephrine coupled with this alteration in electrical rhythm in this increase since it has a ssion the heart goes into ventricular fibrillation what does that I'm sorry ventricular fibrillation or ventricular fibrillation is a rapid alteration in the heart rhythm and such a way that

essentially the heart no longer can mechanically pump the blood and as a result the person goes into cardiac arrest and dies we've seen a significant increase in this at the Haight-Ashbury free medical clinic where individuals are taking cocaine then you see an increased purity of the drug they take a higher dosage and we're seeing a flood of calls of people that are having chest pain

altered heart rhythm they're very concerned about the cardiac effects of cocaine is it cocaine or is it this new pure form called crack that is causing us in other words is it is it the Purity that is the problem today well it's both it's the increased Purity as increased the problem indicators such as seizure and ventricular fibrillation and then in addition the more rapidly you

the cocaine into the blood and the Brain the more problem you have and so crack is a already basa fide form of cocaine that you can smoke it gets into the bloodstream and brain very rapidly you get this rapid increase in cocaine you get this Rush that's Rapid Release and then you get the rapid alteration in heart rhythm can you build up an immunity in other words is it more common to have see this among

people who have only had cocaine one or two times or can anybody have this reaction even if you've taken it for a long period of time anybody can have it Leslie the most the healthiest person in the world can died of a cocaine induced cardiac ventricular fibrillation and arrest part of the problem is that with cocaine you have substantial tolerance so for example we see a large number of people that are addicted to cocaine that are

can very high dosages coming into our inpatient program at Merritt Peralta chemical dependency program over 50 percent of the people are coming in addicted to cocaine so they're using very very high dosages and as a result of this tolerance which means that they take a lot more of the drug to achieve the same effect they may not have as many cardiac or problems as say the Casual user who suddenly has any experience with cocaine and then he

it's exposed to a very high dosage you see situations in which the first time user may be in a room or the series of experienced users gets ahold of some more potent cocaine tries to use the doses that they use and then has this cardiac arrest so first time users chronic abusers anybody can have this problem we're also seeing a major increase in cocaine amongst younger people so you're seeing this

very tragic situation and which adolescents getting involved with cocaine is an upper and alcohol and marijuana is a downer are having these problems obviously adolescence is not an age group in which you have cardiac problems but for example at our forests Farms Adolescent Treatment program the average age is 17 and the favored drug combination is cocaine marijuana and alcohol and you see a significant number of adolescent cocaine abusers

at are using the higher dosages manifesting these types of cardiac symptoms how hard is it to get somebody off a Coke addiction well cocaine is very addicting it leads to compulsion loss of control over the drug and continued use of the drug in spite of adverse consequences and the biggest reason that the person relapse has is because they try to return to a controlled use of the drug just like the try to return a controlled use of alcohol on the other hand

with our inpatient and Outpatient Treatment techniques now we're getting a very good success rate if the person gets into good treatment the biggest problem that we're having is denial a large number of people that have quite serious cocaine problems that are manifesting cocaine addiction or cardiac problems Financial wastage family problems they deny they have the problem they don't get into treatment dr. Smith thank you very
much for being with us we will be right back with the Surgeon General of the United States

two million Americans will have heart attacks or strokes this year more than one-third fatal but according to the Surgeon General dr. C Everett Koop we are gaining ground against the nation's number one killer I think we're winning the battle on heart disease our best marker is death and death rates you have to remember when you talk about Hearts they eventually give out and everybody has to die of something but if you think about

death as being premature death as opposed to Natural expected death we are winning the battle against heart disease are you saying that younger people are having fewer heart attacks I'm saying younger people who have changed their lifestyle having fewer heart attacks I can prove that as well as I'd like to but I know that those people who have cut out smoking which I think is number one are people who are seeing an improvement in the

the death rate from Sudden Death from coronary heart disease and from the symptoms of coronary heart disease what about women it seems that women didn't use to have heart attacks and now we keep reading more and more that women are falling into the same Health pattern as men well what is one of the things that women have done that they didn't used to do the smoking okay and I'm sure that that plays a very large role in it you're becoming a Johnny one note on smoking

well surprisingly I'm not really but it is the number one public health problem in this country and of all the things we've talked about if you wanted to hit the one thing that would bring about the greatest Improvement in cardiovascular disease in this country today it would be kind of smoky do you recommend that people take aspirin to prevent heart disease it's not the prevent heart disease The Taking of an aspirin or two a day

is to increase the ability of your blood to stay fluid it's like an anticoagulant I take an aspirin a day are you saying then that aspirin does actually prevent heart attacks the studies in England that were done in a blind fashion where Physicians were given aspirin or a pill that look like an aspirin with sugar and then after five years did the statistics those who took the aspirin had fewer sudden deaths from coronary disease than did those who took the sugar pills

okay at what age should we all start taking an aspirin a day I don't know that we've ever decided that I started pretty late in life if you would ask me at what age should I start 110 did you were to ask me just off the top of my head what I think would be a good time to start I'd say 42 and a half no kidding federally really well I think

is that right I'm very surprised to hear you say that why would you thought I'd say I thought you would have said 50 how many people in their 40s in a percentage since are having heart attacks or heart problems in this case it's the people in the young age groups who when they do have a coronary problem a more likely to die anything anything on the horizon that might prevent heart disease in terms of a pill or a drug of some kind oh I don't think that's in the cards but I do think that everything I've been talking about is

prevention of heart disease the promotion of Health through diet through exercise through non-smoking through controlled drinking and all the other things that one can control himself all right you mentioned dieting hmm there are a lot of critics lately coming on the scene saying that some of these fad diets that promise you can lose 20 pounds in two weeks or whatever are actually bad for your health do you have a position on that I have a position on it and I stated very very simply this way and that is

is there is nothing that becomes a fad in this country quicker than the suggestion that one could have a diet now many diets are essential there are diets that are good for people who are hypertensive for those who are obese for those who have diabetes and so forth but there was a time just a few years ago I think with 1984 when 10 best sellers on the New York Times nonfiction list eight of those were on diets and I really couldn't find good

to help things in any but one of them what about exercise you mentioned that as a one of the three things people should do to prevent heart disease are Americans exercising enough maybe too much not enough where do you see us in terms of hard say more and more more and more Americans are exercising I think some of them are exercising improperly and I think some of them don't know why they're exercising as I come to work

in the morning and I watch joggers I wonder how many are laying up for them orthopedic problems in the future without doing anything for their hearts and I think we have to recognize there is a kind of activity that's good for any age there's nobody that can't do some kind of exercise but to just jog along and not get your heart rate up and not get up a little sweat and not do the things that the exercise is supposed to do is just giving lip service to it

well dr. versions he uses other people's studies and they to the man disagree to the point I would ask did you call the people who studies are quoted which support what I've said because there were a raft of studies that no exercise enthusiastic ever comments on we you know these people don't do the studies to prove or disprove exercise their done in a double-blind fashion to try and figure out what the truth really is and as you know from the long long term studies of his example Harvard graduates over 25 or 30 years they have a

is the chance of having a heart attack if they exercise and they have an increased life expectancy and that's the best study it's the New England Journal of Medicine yes unfortunately considered the best study and it's faulty on so many grounds that we won't debated here just one ground alone but you're not alone you haven't done this you gentlemen are getting a little too involved in the specifics of that study and we'll come back to it but let's bring in Judy moscovitz who has written a diet book and you heard the surgeon general's say that dieting

is another reason that that we're winning the battle on heart disease but he said that fad diets are not the way to go and your book on the rice diet is the kind of thing that people are calling a fad diet well that's where there's a mistake because it's been it's easy to consider the right side of fad diet based on the name it sounds like it specifies only one food and of course I would not be healthy in fact the rice diet was the precursor of everything we know about nutrition today

he was developed in 1939 by dr. Walter Kepner who is professor emeritus at Duke University he's won the gold medal from the American Heart Association for this very work basically everything that he was saying back in 1939 are now being hailed as the the nutritional discoveries of the 80s but isn't that on your diet where you just eat rice and absolutely not wealthy rice and fruit for for a while to get it for two weeks and this

basically it's a six days diet in which you gradually introduce the new food groupings I don't think that anybody can look into dr. kepner's work and his results for 50 years and call this either ineffective or dangerous it's really dr. Kemp can you see does this in a hospital setting is a positions but it's done a patient but it is still supervised by medical doctors that I go to a bookstore I buy your diet I do is some people in your book say they have done a lose 40 or 50 pounds in two or three weeks and I think

even dr. Solomon would agree with me that that's an excessive amount of weight loss people don't lose 40 pounds and two or three you do say that when your book though that there are several people have lost 40 to 50 pounds in several weeks on your diet well I mentioned two women who would come in over 400 pounds who because of the the enormous amount of obesity lost I would say that the average weight loss on the diet is from 15 to 25 pounds in two weeks you'll lose that weight quickly you have a 99% failure white you destroy your metabolic Machinery while

you lose the white you had cholesterol your coronary arteries as you put it back on you are the exception to the rule most people lose that weight they put it back on and that is dangerous I would argue that I'm not the exception that it's possible for anybody there is no proof that losing weight slowly helps you keep it off it wants took me four months to lose 20 pounds on Weight Watchers and I put it on in two weeks this is a slow diet there are more people who were dying from obesity than are dying from Quick Weight Loss diets get the weight off its unhealthy I want to go

back to the notion that no matter what diet you're on you're going to gain the weight back which I disagree with I need to say one thing in defense of myself I am not in favor of no exercise somebody wants accused me of having a quote lust for making America sedentary I have recommended to everybody a modest exercise program a walking program sedentary living carries a risk happens to be a small one but why accept even a small risk but

more than modest exercise will get you into trouble let's talk about something else that's controversial about your book and that is that you say that women are more vulnerable to injury because of exercise you say that we're more delicate you seem to be saying we are in fact the weaker sex oh don't you're anything but delicate Leslie and women I have not said that what I've said is there a certain anatomical

differences between men and women Vive La difference that makes women more vulnerable to certain types of injury and they have to do with interference with the hormone system women are more subject to fractures to certain kinds of fractions and and they are a woman who exercises seriously who really is an avid exerciser will seriously interfere with her hormonal system may lose her periods

they will become irregular may have may have long-term consequences we don't know yet but certainly abnormal reproductive chemistry saying that you know you have a wonderful imagination there are several thousand women the United States with that particular problem with their endocrine system absolutely there are millions of women in the United States who do not have that problem who exercised and tens of millions of more who should exercise but are being frightened by Miss table I frighten them from any exercise by by saying that women will have their

don't become Runners don't become joggers don't become all that don't go for the burn what a pernicious thought that is go for the burn it's an awful idea Donna you're a marathon runner go for the burn what about that

if someone does a severe amount of exercise many many hours a day and goes absolutely all out there may there may be some risk down the road no one has to find that yet but the fact is why scare people I mean why frightened people because those very few could get some rest when the majority of people don't do enough exercise for more out of shape is our country than we ever have been before there's beginning to develop a certain body of information that suggests that We Are Who We Are

all of these struggles to stop it with exercise dieting aren't going to really interfere with the destiny that we come on this Earth with part of that statement or that question is true there is a genetic inheritance that we all come to our life with that we cannot Escape but a lot of what we inherit we can alter for example you may inherit a tendency to high blood pressure May inherit a metabolism at

is too high cholesterol but we can alter those things part of it is genetic and you know you may have a heart attack at 35 because you're predestined to but you can probably push that back the evidence is that by changing diet and cholesterol and blood pressure and exercise and stress that you really can at least change part of your destiny May devil who died of a heart attack but it's going to be years further down the road well I am surprised that we found something that we all sort of agree on to end and wrap this up I do appreciate you all coming and I thought was very interesting
